Based on my search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about stage adaptations and theatrical productions of Jane Austen's Emma on West End and Broadway:

## Musical Adaptations

Jane Austen's Emma has been adapted into a musical by composer and lyricist Paul Gordon, who was nominated for a 2001 Tony Award for composing the music and lyrics to the musical Jane Eyre. His critically acclaimed musical, Emma, was released worldwide in 2018 on StreamingMusicals.com.

With the option of setting the show either in the Regency Era or mid-century modern, Emma is truly a timeless tale of love, making mistakes, and holding yourself accountable. With flexible casting and minimal design requirements, this show is perfect wheither on a full proscenium stage or in an intimate black box theatre.

## Recent West End and UK Productions

A new stage adaptation of Jane Austen's classic novel Emma is heading out on tour this year. Based on Austen's novel, Emma is adapted by Ryan Craig (What We Did To Weinstein, Filthy Business), and directed by founder of English Touring Theatre and former Rose Theatre head Stephen Unwin (Farm Hall). The tour starts at Theatre Royal Bath from 11 to 20 September 2025, and then visits Guildford, Birmingham, Sheffield, Malvern, and Oxford, with further tour dates to be announced.

## West End Jane Austen Connection

Her novels—continuously reimagined and the inspiration for numerous shows (including current West End productions Clueless The Musical & Austenland), her novels—including Pride and Prejudice, Sense and Sensibility, and Emma—continue to enthral audiences worldwide.

## Historical Stage Adaptations

The first full dramatic version of Emma to be published was Romances by Emma by DeWitt Bodeen in 1938, which was first performed in Pasadena, California. This was followed by Emma by Marion Morse MacKaye; the play was written in 1937 but the author died before its first publication by Macmillan and first performance at the North.

The first big-budget theatrical version of Pride and Prejudice was Helen Jerome's sparky adaptation, which enjoyed successful runs on Broadway in 1935 and in London's West End the following year before going on tour. It is estimated to have been seen by a million people worldwide and was described in the publicity for MGM's 1940 film of Pride and Prejudice (which it directly influenced) as 'One of the most famous plays'. Jerome's adaptation was highly influential, putting more focus on Mr Darcy than the original novel and previous adaptations had done, and turning him into the sexy heartthrob we know today.
